The algorithm's operations grow proportionally to n²
The algorithm is twice as slow as O(n)

questions.correctAnswer: The algorithm's operations grow proportionally to n²
questions.explanation: Big-O describes growth rate. O(n²) means operations grow proportionally to n² (quadratically). It ignores constants and lower-order terms.
In Big-O, we keep only the dominant term (n³) and drop all constants. 5n³ + 100n² + n + 1000 = O(n³).
Two nested loops, each running n times: n × n = n² iterations. Complexity is O(n²).
For O(n²), if n increases by 10×, time increases by 10² = 100×. So 1 second × 100 = 100 seconds.
questions.prompt: An O(n²) algorithm takes 1 second for n=100. How many seconds for n=1000?

questions.explanation: For large n, O(n) always beats O(n²). The constant (1000) doesn't matter asymptotically. At n=1001, A is already faster: 1,001,000 < 1,002,001.
questions.prompt: Which is faster for LARGE n?

questions.explanation: Inner loop runs 1 + 2 + 3 + ... + n = n(n+1)/2 total times. This is O(n²), even though it's "triangular" not "square".
Dense matvec: n² = 1,000,000 operations. Sparse matvec: nnz = 5,000 operations. Speedup: 1,000,000 / 5,000 = 200×.
questions.prompt: A 1000×1000 matrix has 5000 non-zeros. How many times faster is sparse matrix-vector multiply compared to dense?
